feed.title: The blog of Instantbird's development - Comments: Instantbird 1.2 Released!

entry.title: Posted by: Jim
entry.content: I’d also like to know the prospects of other protocols being supported in Thunderbird. I’d like to use ICQ with Thunderbird.

entry.title: Posted by: Jeroen
entry.content: Is it possible to provide the other protocols as add-ons for Thunderbird?

entry.title: Posted by: solid_ice8
entry.content:
Thanks!

I sure am, I even uninstalled Windows Essentials!

entry.title: Posted by: clokep
entry.content: Those lines are totally separate and have nothing to do with each other. “Has You” refers to whether your friend “Has You” as a contact, “Blocked” refers to whether you have them blocked. I hope you’re enjoying using Instantbird!

entry.title: Posted by: solid_ice8
entry.summary:
Hello guys,

I’m a little confused about hovering over a few of my friends on MSN.

Sometimes I see :
“has you No”
“Blocked No”
And sometimes :
“Has you Yes”
“Blocked No”
What does the “Has you” mean?
Is it part of “Has you blocked” as one who line?
Or …
entry.content:
Hello guys,

I’m a little confused about hovering over a few of my friends on MSN.

Sometimes I see :
“has you No”
“Blocked No”
And sometimes :
“Has you Yes”
“Blocked No”
What does the “Has you” mean?
Is it part of “Has you blocked” as one who line?
Or has you added as a friend?

Thanks!

entry.title: Posted by: Instantbird updates with important changes inside

author.name: Instantbird updates with important changes inside

entry.content: […] 1.2 of the open source Instantbird instant messaging (IM) client is now available for Windows, Mac OS X and Linux. The latest version has been ten months in the making; a large […]

entry.title: Posted by: ConnorBehan
entry.summary: Presumably Mozilla was supportive of theThunderbird chat innovation 10 months ago… and then they decided that they would only work on security fixes. It reminds me of how Firefox developers didn’t want to support gstreamer because their mission was to only promote Theora / WebM. And then Mozilla made an …
entry.content:
Presumably Mozilla was supportive of theThunderbird chat innovation 10 months ago… and then they decided that they would only work on security fixes. It reminds me of how Firefox developers didn’t want to support gstreamer because their mission was to only promote Theora / WebM. And then Mozilla made an announcement that Firefox will start playing H.264. Is there a civil war at Mozilla?

Whatever is going on, thanks for all the work. I will continue using both “birds” for a long time.
